abstract.p: Jennifer R Wynn letter disputes John Tierney's August 15 Big City column on accountability in prisons

block.p: Re ''Accountability at Prisons Run Privately,'' by John Tierney (Big City column, Aug. 15):

Mr. Tierney overlooks the fact that large numbers of people now have a vested financial interest in increasing incarceration. Re ''Accountability at Prisons Run Privately,'' by John Tierney (Big City column, Aug. 15):

Mr. Tierney overlooks the fact that large numbers of people now have a vested financial interest in increasing incarceration. Because of privatization's allures (bottom-line returns and less bureaucracy), the number of prison beds under private management grew to 63,595 from 935 between 1985 and 1995.

Also, Mr. Tierney does not ask a profound question: Should one of government's most basic functions -- controlling the lives of people whose freedom has been taken in the name of government -- be delegated to private companies? New York prisons may not be perfect, but New Yorkers have wisely refrained from joining the growing number of states that have abdicated their responsibility for prisoners to profit-driven companies.
JENNIFER R. WYNN New York, Aug. 16, 2000
The writer is director of the Prison Visiting Project, Correctional Association of New York.
